ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about how to do some basic Chemistry lab stuff.
CHEM 136L was a great experience, Prof. Cooper is a wonderful instructor and Sheng was a very helpful TA
Lab procedures and writing long document within due dates
Basic skills related to chemical lab procedures.
I learned basic chemistry-based lab skills.
I learned different laboratory techniques such as spectroscopy and titration, as well as how to collaborate with peers to solve problems.
I learned how to do research and collaborate in research.
Learned Gen Chem skills titrations etc. lab report writing was mildly helpful
Had the opportunity to practice laboratory skills in general chemistry II lab such as titrations, spectrometry, and voltaic cells.
Learned how to write a concise lab report and how to statistically analyze scientific data.
I learned a couple of laboratory techniques, like titration and improved my LoggerPro knowledge.

I developed many lab skills that can be used for chemistry. On top of this, I learned how to communicate well with others because we often worked in partners. I also learned how to be mindful of what I am doing, because many chemistry labs involve specific measurements in order to achieve accurate results.
I built on skills learned in Gen Chem Lab I. You pretty much do slightly more technical labs than in Gen Chem II, some are more fun and more time consuming (ie titrations).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The lab reports are massive but in a way, I guess they kind of have to be.
Strengths are the professor and the shorter labs. Only one lab sucked, but most were fine.
The lab set up was a little further behind than my Chen course I think weekly overlap would help fully tie in concepts.

The course itself was really amplified by Dr. Cooper. I took it previously with Dr. G and had to withdraw, but Dr. Cooper made the workload much more manageable and the material more approachable. Even though I was doing almost identical assignments, I felt much more confident with the material and comfortable working in the lab. The class can be really difficult to do well in if the professor isn't approachable, but Dr. Cooper was.

The workload was made very manageable compared to previous years. I enjoyed the occasional workshops, especially since they gave us more time to work on our lab reports. They also taught us how to analyze our data in excel. Labs were also relatively short, with only a couple taking up the whole lab time.

Some strengths of this class were: instructor would post lecture videos prior to lab so that we could understand what we were going to do, a helpful TA, workshops to enhance skills, and clear lab guides. Weaknesses: it would be helpful if prelab quizzes were graded towards completion instead of accuracy, and if the answers were posted after submitting them.
No weaknesses! I loved how the prelab were so informative.
Really good well organized course. More office hours would be nice

Strengths: very well organized course, well designed experiments, and fantastic support from TA and Dr. Cooper
Weaknesses: lab reports were a bit long and could have been shortened or been more consistently spread out

Strengths: good at improving and using the statistical analysis with science
Weakness: lab work was not that exciting
Sometimes the lab was quite long and involved a lot of waiting, on other days it was more engaging.
I feel that I did not do much more experiments that I had not already done in CHEM 134L, which made the course feel a bit boring.
Lab templates need to be more specific. Lots of time spent trying to understand what the lab was asking rather than actually answering the questions.

The course is pretty great. Sometimes the purpose of the experiment didn't become clear until writing the lab report, which I guess is the point of the lab report. Otherwise great resources in both Prof Cooper and TA Sheng.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you need the lab credit.
Only if you have to take it otherwise never
Yes, if it's a requirement for their major.
If you need this course as a requirement, I would recommend taking Gen Chem 2 Lab with Dr. Cooper.
Yes! You learn a lot of research.
Yes! If this course is required for your major, definitely take it with Dr. Cooper. Well organized and fun course that helps corroborate what you learn in lecture.
I would recommend for any bio chem majors, but not to anyone outside of those majors since the workload is a lot and the lab work not that exciting.
Unless you are required to do it for your major I would not recommend taking it. Its too much work for only 0.5 credits.

I would probably recommend this course because it helps develop valuable skills that can be translated into other work, like other labs even if they are biological rather than chemical. I would particularly recommend taking it off sequence because the professors give you more attention than they could if taken on sequence.

Prof Cooper is very helpful and understanding so I recommend taking this specific course if you need it to fill any requirements. He is a great prof who helps you understand the experiment and concepts.
